title: When will I be evicted if a judgement creditor gets a writ of execution on my house? When would I be evicted if I go bankrupt?
question: My house is paid off and worth $250K. I have a declared homestead that gives us $175K. I have $100K in 3 year old credit card debt. Recently, two debt buyers have got judgements against me. Is there anything I can do? If not, how long will we be homeless before we receive the 175K from the homestead to purchase another house?
question_tags: Child support,Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy estate,Debt,Nondischargeable debt and student loans,Secured debt,Bankruptcy and debt
answers: Your debt collectors with judgments against may slap liens on house but they shouldn't foreclose (very rare). So being homeless doesn't sound like a serious threat with these facts. Generally it's mortgage liens that foreclose in Cali, not judicial liens. When you go and sell house in future, if creditors slapped liens on house, they will get paid. To avoid this, file BK, but with unprotected equity, trustee may want to liquidate, cut you a check for $175K (if you properly exempted) good towards purchase of another house. Or go Ch 13, pay back creditors the unprotected equity portion (over 5 years max, 0% interest) and be done with them. But you have to show the ability to pay them. Example with this facts: $250K value. 8% sales cost = $20K (if anyone were to sell house). $230K net equity - $175K exempted (if disabled, over certain age, retirement age, etc etc, CCCP 704) = $55K unprotected asset worth. Means in Ch 13 you're paying min $55K over 5 years = $916/month (and don't forget to add trustee fee of 11% and any attorney fees). So maybe $1K/month in Ch 13, you keep your house with NO liens and pay back half your debt. Otherwise, settle with judgment creditors at 30 cents on dollar and hope the others you owe money to don't take their place in line. $100K in unsecured debt is nothing to sneeze at. Good news you have value in your stuff. Bad news you have debt you need to contend with. But there are ways out of everything without going homeless. That's sounds like an extreme scenario that I simply don't see happening (but life it full of surprises I suppose).

Sounds like you did not contest the creditor's claim. If you had, the attorney could provide you with an answer. The creditor has to initiate an action to sell your homesteaded property. If you receive any such documents, court papers make sure to expeditiously hire an attorney to protect your interest and provide you with guidance. A certified bankruptcy specialist or other experienced attorney is what you need

I strongly suggest you sit down with an experienced bankruptcy attorney in CA to discuss all the facts which is beyond this type of forum. It is great you have substantial equity in your house. And you should want to discuss how to start fresh . But other issues and facts can gravely affect your case so I will point out several next for you to hopefully make you understand you ONLY need to remember ONE thing to do: Find an experienced bankruptcy attorney!

You need and want to enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts. If you don't have any of the exceptions to discharge you will obtain that goal; most exceptions are set forth in 11 USC. 523 (Google it) like child support, some income taxes, traffic (in a ch 7) and criminal fines , and presumption of student loans. But some debts are dischargeable in a ch 13 but NOT in a ch 7 so you want to make sure and your attorney will discuss any such types with you also!

Your exemptions depend on what state you have lived in in the last 2 years and thus if in your state, then your states exemptions will apply. Most persons filing keep everything they own but your attorney will confirm that with you when they learn everything you own and the equity thereof!

Some secured debts like homes, vehicles, other secured debts an attorney will discuss your options on also as you must list any debts; but that does not mean you will lose them unless you have too much equity or are in default on paying for them! Discuss those options if they apply with your attorney too.

But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so meet with one no matter what.

Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one as soon as you can.

You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of waiting versus filing now and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.
